awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Leveraging rapid evolution to study the dynamics of polygenic adaptation
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021,
Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes,
Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that
will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. The fellow will conduct research
focusing on polygenic traits, which are defined as the physical characteristics, or phenotypes, of
an organism that are influenced by many genes located throughout an individual’s genome.
Examples of polygenic traits include numerous human diseases and the resilience of coral reefs
to global climate change. The fellow will conduct experiments to understand: (1) how genetic
differences between individuals give rise to differences in the physical expression of polygenic
traits and (2) how polygenic traits evolve in natural populations. Through this, the fellow largely
aims to lend insight into the extent to which genetic information can be used to accurately predict
an individual’s phenotype. Throughout the duration of this fellowship, the fellow will engage in
outreach efforts that specifically aim to increase the participation of underrepresented groups in
evolutionary biology.

To resolve the genetic basis and evolutionary dynamics of polygenic traits, the fellow
will study populations of Drosophila melanogaster as they rapidly evolve in response to seasonal
fluctuations in the environment. This system provides a lens to directly observe evolution and
selection, both on individual genes and specific polygenic traits throughout the course of
adaptation. This work will focus on three polygenic traits in D. melanogaster with demonstrated
ecological relevance in natural populations. The first aim of the fellow’s research will involve
mapping the genetic basis of each trait as it rapidly evolves between seasons. Through this, the
fellow aims to determine whether the genotype-to-phenotype map is stable during evolution, or
whether the genetic basis of polygenic traits is altered by the evolutionary process. The second
aim will leverage these results, in combination with 7 years of existing data, to explore the extent to
which those genetic polymorphisms that underpin the phenotypic variation of a polygenic trait
are the same as those that respond to natural selection and drive the evolution of the trait through
time. The fellow will further gain extensive formal and informal training in preparation for a
career of academic research and teaching.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Evolutionary adaptation has long been considered a gradual process, shaping patterns of species diversity over the course of millennia. However, recent evidence suggests that adaptation can sometimes proceed rapidly, and on a timescale that can be measured and studied by humans. Understanding the conditions that give rise to rapid adaptation and the underlying principles of the process are relevant to myriad issues of societal concern ? from the progression of cancer tumors to the persistence of natural species under climate change.

One useful system for studying rapid adaptation is temperate regions, such as the Northeastern United States, where changing seasons can cause dramatic fluctuations in the environment. For the fruit fly, Drosophila melanogaster, these seasonal fluctuations can cause populations to rapidly adapt, whereby flies collected in the winter are, for example, better able to handle extreme cold stress and low food conditions than flies collected in the summer. These physical (or ?phenotypic?) differences can be traced to differences in the DNA of flies collected across seasons.

This project leveraged rapid evolution across seasons to: (1) resolve how finely populations can adapt to changes in their environment and (2) understand of how traits with complex genetic bases evolve.

(1)  Resolving the pace of rapid adaptation ? To study rapid adaptation across seasons we used a system of outdoor cages, or ?mesocosm?, which is exposed to the natural environmental conditions of Philadelphia, PA, USA.  At the onset of summer, we seeded twelve replicate mesocosm cages with 1000 flies from a population originally collected in local Pennsylvania orchards. We sampled the populations twelve times between 13 July and 20 December. At every collection time point, we collected 100 flies from each replicate, extracted their DNA, and calculated the frequency 1.9 million mutations throughout their DNA.

We identified changes in the DNA of the populations that indicated repeated evolution on weekly timescales. Strikingly, we saw that the direction of evolution fluctuated continuously thorough the experiment ? mutations that were favored for one week (i.e., increased the chances of survival), become rapidly disfavored in the subsequent week. Our findings indicate that rapid temporal fluctuations in environmental conditions may be an important force maintaining diversity in natural populations. Furthermore, these results demonstrate the power of adaptation to finely track shifting environmental conditions, such as those occurring as a result of climate change.

(2)  Exploring the genetic basis of complex trait evolution: Genetics research oftentimes focuses on phenotypic traits with ?simple? genetic bases ? i.e., traits that are controlled by one or a few genes in an individual?s genome. For example, in humans, an individual?s blood type is controlled by their DNA sequence at the ABO gene. However, many traits are governed by 10?s-1000?s of genes and are referred to as ?complex? traits. One potential benefit of understanding the genes controlling complex traits is to effectively predict and/or manipulate the evolutionary process. For example, if we know the genes involved in extreme heat tolerance in corals, could we manipulate their genetics in order to allow them to thrive in future oceans? While an intriguing concept in theory, it may not hold in practice. Specifically, while one may identify a large impact of a gene on a particular trait in a lab-based setting, this approach overlooks how the gene impacts the organism in the context of the far more dynamic, ?natural?, setting in which it lives and evolves.

We leveraged rapid adaptation across seasons in D. melanogaster to gain better insight into whether we can use our knowledge of a trait?s genetic basis to predict its evolution through time. Specifically, a complex trait that evolves between summer and fall is pigmentation ? flies become lighter as population sizes expand and the weather warms throughout summer. At two time points during our mesocosm study, we isolated the 15% lightest and 15% darkest flies. We sequenced the genomes of these groups and identified several genes containing mutations that strongly differentiated the lightest from darkest flies. However, we found that only a subset of these genes had mutations that impacted fly pigmentation evolution in the field experiment. We hypothesize this is due to the fact that some genes impact multiple traits, not just pigmentation. For example, a gene may have mutations that cause lighter pigmentation, but at the cost of a decrease in thermal tolerance. Thus, it is of a net advantage to not use this mutation during adaptation across seasons, as it would affect pigmentation in an advantageous way, but heat tolerance in a negative manner. This project suggests we need to use caution in predicting or manipulating the evolution of complex traits.

This research has provided training opportunity for several undergraduate and graduate students. The results have been presented at numerous international conferences and a manuscript associated with this research is publicly available at: https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.10.16.562586v1.
